Graphical abstract Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction activity depends on the formation of active NiMoS (completely sulfided multilayer type 2 sites) and inactive NiAl2O4/NixSy phases on the catalyst surface. These inactive phases not only itself inactive for the reaction but also hinder the formation of active NiMoS phases. In addition, the formation of strong Mo-O-Al bonds also lowers the reducibility of the catalyst, suggesting lesser catalytic activity (type 1 sites, partially sulfided single-layer sites). To this end, we report the formation of NiMo/Ga doped amorphous alumina (A-Al2O3) catalysts prepared by the colloidal synthesis method. A-Al2O3 was chosen as a support because it has lower surface energy, better physicochemical properties, and enhanced acidic sites than the crystalline alumina phase, which favours the formation of type 2 sites or weak metal-support interaction (completely sulfided multilayer NiMoS sites). Further, the Ga doping in A-Al2O3 support substitute the tetrahedral Al sites and form GaAl2O4 phases by reducing NiAl2O4 inactive sites, and the free Ni decorate the edges of MoS2 to form HDS active NiMoS sites. Therefore, NiMo/Ga doped A-Al2O3 catalyst (at 1 wt% Ga loading) reported enhanced HDS catalytic activity (25%), HDS reaction rate constant (kHDS-2.15 times) and turn over frequency (TOF-1.3 times) than the conventional NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a catalytic process, which is used in petroleum refineries to reach zero sulfur level of energy fuels due to its higher rate and activity for desulfurization [1–3]. For NiMo-based HDS catalysts (e.g., NiMo@support), NiMoS (Ni doped MoS2 or Ni-MoS2) sites are considered as the active sites [4] which form during the sulfidation process of the prepared oxide phase catalysts (Ni-MoO3). [5,6] The formation of active NiMoS sites further depends on the reducibility of the catalysts.[2,3,7–9] For conventional catalysts (NiMo/CoMo@γ-Al2O3), strong metal support interaction of Mo with γ-Al2O3 support forming strong Mo-O-Al bond hinders the conversion of Ni-MoO3 to Ni-MoS2 which leads to low formation of active NiMoS sites.[10,11] In addition, the interaction of the Ni promoter with the supports producing inactive spinels (i.e., NiAl2O4) also limits the formation of active NiMoS sites.[12,13] Furthermore, the inactive NixSy phases (which block the NiMoS sites at the perimeter) segregate and form on the catalyst surface due to their thermodynamically favorable nature in the given HDS conditions. [14–16] Therefore, the conventional available catalysts (NiMo/CoMo@γ-Al2O3) are not active enough for the complete removal of sulfur compounds from energy fuels due to strong metal-support interaction, inactive sites formation and poor active metal dispersion [17,18] (low control over particle size and growth) [13,19]. Various approaches were explored to target these challenges, such as 1) the use of different catalyst supports, e.g., zeolite [3,20,21], SBA 15 or SBA 16 [22], composite of zeolite and alumina/SBA 15 [22–27] etc., 2) preparation techniques for better control over size and dispersion properties as sol–gel [28,29], co-precipitation [30,31], hydrothermal [20,24], self-assembly, [32] colloidal synthesis [2,7,8] etc., and 3) Ni sulfide segregates removal was also treated through acid leaching for unsupported NiMo catalysts [33]. Recently, some reports discussed a series of new composites such as NiS2-MoS2 flower like hybrid catalysts having minimum slab length to stacking degree ratio and enhanced NiMo interactions [34], NiMo/dendritic silica catalysts containing dendritic open channels, high surface area and acidic sites [35], NiMo/Al modified yolk shell silica (moderate shell size and small yolk which give better structure stability and moderate metal-support interaction) particles [36]. These catalyst compositions showed enhanced activity for HDS reaction at given conditions. However, the catalysts are still unable to reach the desired sulfur limit [37,38]. Our previous articles [39,40] reported the formation of highly active NiMo supported on amorphous alumina (A-Al2O3) catalysts using a colloidal synthesis approach for HDS reaction[41]. These reports proved that the structure of prepared amorphous alumina possesses four [Al]4 and five [Al]5 coordinated sites dominantly (95 %) along with few six [Al]6 coordinated sites, which leads to more unsaturated lewis acid sites available on the surface than γ-Al2O3 (consist of [Al]4 and [Al]6 sites). A-Al2O3 also showed lower surface energy (offering lesser driving force for interactions towards any external molecule; see previous articles [39,40]) and higher surface area than γ-Al2O3. Due to this, A-Al2O3 supported catalysts represented higher acidic sites and weak-metal support interactions (higher Ni-Mo interaction producing NiMoS sites), leading to enhanced type 2 sites, higher sulfidation and dispersion properties, which ultimately showed enhanced HDS catalytic activity than NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [40]. Further, doping of various metals (Ir, Ga and Zr) into γ-Al2O3 support was explored to suppress the formation of inactive spinels so that the free Ni can interact with Mo to form active NiMoS sites [12,13,19,42,43]. Among all, Ga is considered the most appropriate dopant because of its physical and chemical similarities to Al, i.e., Ga is a trivalent element from group 13 (same as Al) having average electron negativity (1.59) lower than Al (1.74), and Ga also possesses smaller size than Al due to its poor shielding effect [13,19–21,42–47]. Therefore, Ga has a higher affinity to replace the tetrahedral Al sites in alumina support. Many articles reported that the Ga doping technique in γ-Al2O3 for HDS catalysts avoids the Ni participation in inactive spinel formation (NiAl2O4) by reacting with alumina. Also, Ga doping in zeolite supports showed enhanced HDS performance by controlling its acidic properties via Al/Si ratio reduction (Ga replaces Al sites) [20,21,43]. To the best of our knowledge, no report is available in the literature addressing simultaneously all these problems mentioned above (strong metal-support interactions, inactive NiAl2O4 and NixSy phases, control over particle size and dispersion) in a single HDS catalyst so that it can overcome all the barriers combinedly and show superior HDS performance. It is worth noting here that the very first mentioned challenge (strong MoOAl bond) can be easily addressed by replacing the γ-Al2O3 support with A-Al2O3 and the last two challenges can be targeted by using acid leaching method (removal of inactive NixSy phases) along with preparing the catalysts via colloidal synthesis approach (higher dispersion of active metal). Further, inactive NiAl2O4 spinels can be targeted by doping Ga in A-Al2O3 support. To this end, this work report the formation of NiMo supported on Ga doped amorphous alumina (Ga-A-Al2O3) catalysts by a colloidal synthesis approach. Our previous work summarized that for 20 % metal oxide composition, NiMo/A-Al2O3 catalyst synthesized by one step colloidal synthesis method, exhibited highest activity enhancement (15 %) than conventional wet impregnated NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Adopting these superior properties of this catalyst, Ga doping (Ga wt.% varied from 0.75-2.1 wt% through two different ways) in A-Al2O3 is studied in this work and showed that Ga successfully replaced the tetrahedral Al sites in A-Al2O3 (confirmed by XPS, TPR and XRD, see the following sections) and enhanced the formation of NiMoS sites due to higher NiMo interactions. However, it is noticed that the activity increased first for 0.75–1 wt% Ga doping and then decreased for 1–2.1 wt% range, suggesting that a small amount of Ga enhances Ni-Mo interaction by avoiding the formation of strong Mo-O-Al bond and inactive NiAl2O4 spinels, but it starts to form strong Mo-O-Ga and nickel gallium spinels along with isolated Ga2O3 phases at higher Ga doping. The DFT studies are also performed to support the importance of Ga doping experimental studies, and the calculated adsorption energy values suggested that the metal support interaction is weaker for Ga doped alumina surfaces as compared to bare alumina surfaces for both bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 adsorbates. Further, along with the Ga doping study, this work also proposed a NiMo/Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst treated via acid leaching method to selectively remove the inactive NixSy segregates to further enhance the HDS activity. The detailed study of these NixSy segregates is available in our second report [39], which showed the drastic shoot up of HDS performance for these catalysts. This proposed catalyst is prepared by combining three strategies (A-Al2O3 support, Ga doping and acid treatment), simultaneously enabling it to address all the mentioned problems (lower reducibility, control over size and dispersion, inactive spinels and inactive Ni sulfide segregates). 2 Experimental details 2.1 Material All analytical grade materials and chemicals were used in this work, and no further treatment was performed on these supplied chemicals before they were used in the experiments. To prepare Ga doped NiMo supported on A-Al2O3 catalysts, nickel acetylacetonate (Ni(acc)2 Sigma Aldrich, 95 %), molybdenum hexacarbonyl (Mo(CO)6, Sigma Aldrich, 98 %), aluminium nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Thomas Baker, 99 %)) and gallium nitrate (Ga(NO3)2, 99.9 %) precursors were used as source of Ni, Mo, Al and Ga respectively. Along with these precursors, three surfactants trioctylphosphine (TOP, Sigma Aldrich, 97 %), oleic acid (OA, Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) and olylamine (OAM, Sigma Aldrich, 70 %) were also used in catalyst preparation process. 2.2 NiMo nanocluster synthesis First NiMo nanoclusters were prepared, starting with the addition of Ni and Mo precursors in the required amount (0.16 gm Ni(acc)2 and 0.42 gm Mo(CO)6) and the surfactants (0.5 ml TOP, 0.5 ml OA and 15 ml OAM) in a three-neck flask, which was heated to 230 ℃ with vigorous stirring at 5 K/min heating rate. At 230 ℃, the sample was maintained at the same condition for 10 min, and then heating was stopped to cool the sample immediately. The sample was collected in a separate container after it was washed with acetone and dried overnight. These nanoclusters are used to prepare other samples; no calcination was performed for these nanoclusters to avoid the agglomeration of particles [2,7,8]. 2.3 Support synthesis Bare A-Al2O3 support was also prepared separately by using the above-mentioned colloidal synthesis method (which was used to prepare NiMo nanoclusters) in which only aluminium nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Thomas Baker 99 %, amount calculated based on the required amount of alumina, 20 wt% NiMo and 80 wt% alumina) precursor was added with the surfactants (0.5 ml TOP, 0.5 ml OA and 15 ml OAM). After washing and drying, the collected sample was also calcined at 550 ℃ for 2 h to remove the surfactants. Two different doping methods (in-situ and wet impregnation) were explored by varying the Ga doping content from 0.75-2.1 wt%. First, in-situ Ga-doped A-Al2O3 (named Ga-A-Al2O3) support was prepared by adding Ga(NO3)2 (0.75–2.1 wt%) and (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Thomas Baker)) precursor with all three surfactants (0.5 ml TOP, 0.5 ml OA and 15 ml OAM) in three a neck flask, which was heated to 230 ℃ and after staying at this point for 10 min, the sample is cooled immediately. Then the material was washed, dried and finally calcined at 550 ℃ for 2 h. Second, the Ga doping was performed by wet impregnation method in A-Al2O3 and commercially available γ-Al2O3, then these supports Ga-A-Al2O3-W/Ga-γ-Al2O3-W (where, W-Ga doping by wet impregnation method) were used to prepare the NiMo catalysts. In this typical procedure, an aqueous solution of Ga(NO3)2 was added dropwise to the required amount of separately prepared bare A-Al2O3/supplied γ-Al2O3 and stirred for 1 h vigorously. After evaporating the excess solvent, the collected sample was dried for 2 h at 100 ℃. 2.4 Catalyst synthesis For NiMo supported on Ga-doped alumina catalysts, the prepared NiMo nanoclusters were mixed physically with synthesized Ga-A-Al2O3/Ga-A-Al2O3-W/Ga-γ-Al2O3-W supports (where, W-Ga doping by wet impregnation method). In this procedure, the required nanoclusters and support were dispersed in excess hexane and stirred continuously for 12 h to distribute the clusters uniformly on the surface of the support. Then, the sample was washed with acetone and dried overnight in the oven at 100 ℃. Finally, the catalyst sample was calcined at 550 ℃ for 2 h. The final prepared samples were named NiMo@(x)Ga-A-Al2O3, where x is the Ga wt.% dopped in amorphous alumina. Ga doping varied from 0.75-2.1 wt%, NiMo metal oxide content was fixed at 20 wt% with constant Ni/Ni + Mo ratio-0.31 or Ni/Mo-0.4, and total Ga doped support is 80 wt% in all the prepared samples. One undoped sample was also prepared for comparison by using bare A-Al2O3. This sample is named NiMo@A-Al2O3. Two control catalysts NiMo supported on Ga doped alumina (A-Al2O3/γ-Al2O3) named NiMo@(1)-Ga-A-Al2O3-Wet and NiMo@(1)-Ga-γ-Al2O3-W-Wet were prepared by wet impregnation method (where W-Ga doping by wet impregnation method and Wet-catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method). For this preparation process, required amounts of Ni and Mo precursors were added in citric acid aqueous solution (0.21 gm/ml), and this final solution was added dropwise in the required amount of support (separately prepared Ga-A-Al2O3 and Ga-γ-Al2O3-W) and stirred for 1 h vigorously. Then, after evaporating the excess solvent, the sample was dried for 2 h. The final material was collected by calcining it at 550 ℃ for 2 h. One undoped NiMo@γ-Al2O3-Wet catalyst was also prepared by the same wet impregnation method using supplied γ-Al2O3 support without doping. Finally NiMo supported on Ga doped alumina after leaching (L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst, where L-leached catalyst samples) was prepared by performing the acid leaching method of the sulfided NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst (sulfiding procedure given in the following section). In this method, the sulfided catalyst sample was treated with concentrated HCl acid for 1 h in an inert atmosphere and then washed with water, followed by acetone washing. This process was repeated 3 more times, and finally, the collected material was dried in a vacuum and directly used for HDS reaction. 2.5 Comparison procedure for various prepared samples (1) Various composition NiMo@(x)Ga-A-Al2O3 as well as NiMo@(x)Ga-A-Al2O3-W samples are compared to screen the optimized composition sample for both types of doping. (2) NiMo@(x)Ga-A-Al2O3 and NiMo@(x)Ga-A-Al2O3-W are compared to each other at fixed x value to study the better doping technique. (3) NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 and NiMo@A-Al2O3 as well as NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W-wet and NiMo@(1)γ-Al2O3-Wet analysed together to see the doping effect. (4) NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W and NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3-W are studied to analyse the samples with respect to support. (5) NiMo@(1)-Ga-A-Al2O3-Wet and NiMo@(1)-Ga-A-Al2O3 are analysed with respect to the preparation method. (6) NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 and L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 are analysed together to study the acid leaching effect. (7) The best catalyst is screened by comparing the current approach with conventional wet-impregnated sample NiMo@γ-Al2O3-Wet. 2.6 Catalyst characterization At 77 K, N2 adsorption–desorption test was performed on prepared catalyst samples (oxide phase/unsulfided catalysts) on Autosorb-1C (Model: AS1-C, Quantachrome, USA) instrument. This approach was used to calculate the pore size, pore volume, and specific surface area. Prior to the test, samples were degassed at 280 °C for a minimum of three hours. Several catalyst samples (oxide phase/unsulfided catalysts) were analysed for elemental compositions using X-ray fluorescence (XRF, ZSX Primus II XRF spectrometer by Rigaku) machine. Under 15–20 bar of pressure, catalyst samples were pelletized in a hydraulic machine using boric acid as a substrate. At 100 mA and 30 kV, Al was found, while Ni/Mo was detected at 60 mA and 50 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to characterize the produced catalyst (oxide phase/unsulfided catalysts) using a PAN analytical X-ray diffractometer with Ni-filtered K radiation and a Cu target (=1.541841). All patterns were recorded between 10 and 80 degrees at a scan rate of 3 degrees per minute. Utilizing X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (PHI Versa Probe II scanning XPS microprobe), the various chemical states of sulfided and unsulfided catalyst samples were determined. The sulfided samples were stored in inert atmosphere before characterization because the samples may again oxidize, if exposed to air. XPS 4.1 peak software was used to fit the various peaks of the samples. FTIR spectroscopy was performed using a spectrum II PerkinElmer instrument in attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode with a germanium (Ge) crystal from 500 to 4000 cm−1. Using high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and a Tecnai TM G2 U-Twin (200 kV, FEI) instrument equipped with an energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) detector, the morphology and average particle size of several catalyst samples (unsulfided and sulfided samples stored in inert atmosphere before characterization) were analysed. After ultrasonically treating a drop of this dispersed liquid sample, HRTEM samples were created by dispersing the catalyst sample in ethanol solvent and placing a drop of this sample on a carbon-coated copper grid. The sample was then vacuum-dried. The average particle size of metal oxide nanoclusters was determined using the following formula (Eq. (1)), where ni is the number of nanoclusters with size di. (1) size avg = ∑ i = 1 n n i d i ∑ i = 1 n n i These evaluations were made with six HRTEM images with 50 nanoclusters per image (total 300 clusters). HRTEM images of sulfided catalyst samples were utilized to calculate the average slab size (Lavg) of MoS2 slabs present in the sample and the stacking degree using the following equation: (Navg). (2) L avg = ∑ i = 1 n n i L i ∑ i = 1 n n i ; N avg = ∑ i = 1 n n i N i ∑ i = 1 n n i where ni is the number of stacks of slab length li and Ni is the number of layers within each stack. fMo is the Mo edge sites fraction (Eqs. (3)–(4)), which represents the proportion of Mo atoms present at the edge sites. It was also approximated via statistically calculated methods assuming MoS2 crystallites were perfect hexagons [48]: (3) f Mo = ∑ i = 1 . . . t 6 n i - 6 / ∑ i = 1 . . . t 3 n i 2 - 3 n i + 1 (4) n i = L 6.4 + 0.5 Turn over frequency (TOF) was calculated using Eq. (5) based on the edge MoS2 dispersion (calculated from Eq. (3)) which is basically the fraction of available edge sites over total Mo sites present at the surface of the catalyst. (5) TOF = F × N × X Moe = F × N × X N Mo × N × f Mo = F × X N Mo × f Mo where, X is the DBT conversion at a given temperature, NMo is the mol of molybdenum, fMo is the Mo edge sites fraction, N is Avogadro number and F is the molar flow rate of DBT. Using the Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) method, the reducibility of the various produced materials (oxide phase/unsulfided catalysts) was determined. All TPR studies were conducted using the Quantachrome instrument and 5 % (v/v) H2 in N2 gas. Before the experiments, the TPR samples were degassed in He atmosphere at 200 °C for 2 h, and after cooling to room temperature in an inert gas atmosphere, 5 %H2 in N2 gas was purged at 10 ml/min at 40 °C. In addition, samples were heated continuously from 40 °C to 1000 °C at a rate of 15 °C/min. Utilizing the thermal conductivity detector (TCD), the H2 consumption values were calculated. 2.7 Computational method We have adopted the methodology given in our previous paper to compute the adsorption of bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 on Ga doped crystalline and amorphous alumina (A-Al2O3) surfaces [49]. A brief discussion of the computational method is as follows: All the calculations were performed by density functional theory (DFT) using a projected augmented wave method −generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh functional (PBE), as implemented in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [50]. A Plane wave cut-off energy was set 1.3 times the maximum default value to get a complete basis set for all calculations (bulk, surface and adsorption of the molecule on surfaces) [51–53]. For Brillouin zone integration, we have employed a Monkhorst-Pack grid of (8 × 8 × 8) for both the bulk crystalline and amorphous Al2O3. The amorphous alumina was constructed using the method reported by Lizarraga et al. and quantum ATK simulation software, which has been well explored in literature [54]. The cubic box for the amorphous structure has a volume of 1000 cm3 and a density 3.1 g/cm3. Further, fully optimized crystalline and amorphous bulk unit cells have been considered for surface calculations with a vacuum thickness of ∼20 A0. For surface calculations, Brillouin zone sampling was performed using MP grid of (6 × 4 × 1) for crystalline, (4 × 4 × 1) for amorphous, and (8 × 8 × 1) for MoS2. Further, 1 wt% Ga doping has been done in both the (110) surface of crystalline alumina and amorphous alumina surfaces (decided based on the results of experimental work). The adsorption energy of bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 on Ga-doped crystalline and amorphous alumina has been calculated by following equation: (6) E adsorption = E Slab + a d s o r b a t e - E slab - E adsorbate where, Eslab+adsorbate is the combined energy of molecule adsorbed on the crystal slab, Eslab is the energy of the clean slab, and Eadsorbate is the energy of the isolated adsorbate (molecule). 2.8 Catalytic activity As the sulfided phase of the catalyst is believed to be the active phase for the HDS reaction, the metal oxide catalysts were sulfided (sulfidation procedure Fig. S1) in the stainless steel reactor (Fig. S2). The catalyst was sulfided in the presence of hydrogen (H2) at a flow rate of 120 ml/min at a pressure of 30 bar using a solution of 10 mol% dimethyl disulfide (DMDS) in n-heptane as the sulfiding agent. The flow rate of the sulfiding solution was maintained at 0.17 ml/min throughout all trials. All HDS reactions were conducted at a pressure of 30 bar, 150 mg of catalyst weight and a temperature range of 275–335 °C with a 1.68 wt% DBT solution in n-decane, and a 0.80 wt% 4, 6 DMDBT solution in n-decalin. To maintain 30 bar H2 pressure in the reactor, initially, the pressure was increased to 10 bar using helium gas, then helium gas was gently replaced with H2 gas and the pressure was increased to 30 bar with a combined flow of 120 ml/min of H2 and 0.17 ml/min of liquid feed solution. Before collecting the product sample corresponding to a specific temperature, the sample was allowed to stay at that temperature for at least one hour to stabilize it properly. All samples were evaluated using a gas chromatography (GC) machine with a Petrocol DH capillary column (length-100 m and diameter-0.25 mm) and a flame ionization detectot (FID) to calculate the conversion values (Eq. (7)) at different temperatures. (7) Conversion % = Moles of reactant in - M o l e s o f r e a c t a n t o u t Moles of reactant in × 100 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization The prepared catalyst samples were characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption BET test to evaluate the material surface area and pore size values (Table 1 ). Table 1 shows the samples representing two ways of Ga doping: 1) in-situ within the support (A-Al2O3) preparation and 2) wet impregnation, along with control catalysts. Both doping techniques were used to prepare four samples each by varying Ga content from 0.75-2.1 wt%. It is clear from the table that all the samples reported surface area in the range of 210–240 m2/g, pore volume 0.25–0.30 and pore size 4–5 nm. No significant change was observed in the whole series of samples, but the surface area and volume were still decreased to approx. 8–9 % for 2.1 wt% doping samples. This finding is well reported in the literature [19,43,45,46,55]. This leads to fact that all the physicochemical properties are maintained unaffected by substitution of Ga3+ to Al3+ ions in the catalyst support. However, γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst showed lower surface area based on the γ-Al2O3 support properties (possess lower surface area than A-Al2O3). Table 1 also shows the doped Ga wt.% content in all prepared catalyst samples, and the Ga wt.% values almost match the theoretical values for in-situ doping samples, but the samples prepared through wet impregnation doping showed a significant loss of Ga. Therefore, the in-situ doping technique seems to be a more accurate method than the wet impregnation. Ni/Ni + Mo atomic ratio was maintained fixed (0.30, well-known optimum range 0.28–0.32) for all samples [56]. The synthesized supports and catalyst samples were characterized by XRD technique and shown in Figs. 1 and 2 , respectively. The support XRD pattern (Fig. 1) represents that the Ga doping (both techniques) has not affected the structure of the bare support (for both crystalline, γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 10–0425) and amorphous alumina). Additionally, for A-Al2O3 support, the formation of alumina is further confirmed by XPS, as its amorphous nature cannot only be confirmed by XRD (Fig. S3). In Fig. 2, all the Ga-doped catalyst samples represent a major peak at phase angle 26.5° matching with NiMoO4 (JCPDS 45-0142) phase along with γ-Al2O3 support peaks for control catalyst NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W-Wet and no other peak corresponding the support for A-Al2O3 alumina supported catalyst. However, no peak was observed for separate Ga2O3 phase even for the 2.1 wt% sample, which leads to the possibility of Ga substitution to the Al tetrahedral sites. But it may also happen due to the highly dispersed small crystallite size (<4 nm) of the Ga2O3 phase, which is out of the XRD detectable limit. This thing is further analyzed using the XPS characterization method and discussed in the following sections. The TPR profile of all synthesized catalyst samples is shown in Fig. 3 . All the prepared catalyst samples represent two main reduction peaks in the temperature range of 200–900 ℃. The lower temperature peak corresponds to the reduction of Mo+6 to Mo+4, and the higher temperature peak refers to the reduction step of Mo+4 to Mo0. Compared to undoped samples (NiMo@A-Al2O3), the Ga-doped samples possess easier reduction for 0.75–1 wt% doping as the reduction peaks are shifted to lower temperatures. Then again, reducibility decreased for 1–2.1 wt% Ga doped samples i.e., NiMo@(2.1)Ga-A-Al2O3 represent 16 ℃ temperature shift towards higher temperature value from NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3. It suggest that Ga doping in catalyst support has reduced the metal-support interaction (well supported by DFT studies, see the following section), and maximum reducibility was observed for 1 wt% Ga doped (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) catalyst sample. These findings are well supported by literature reports [19,20,45,46,55]. The expected reason behind this observed trend may be the substitution of Ga for tetrahedral Al sites up to 1 wt% and Ga concentration > 1 wt%, it started replacing the octahedral Al sites and forming separate Ga2O3 phases, strong Mo-O-Ga bonds and inactive nickel gallium spinels. Therefore, the formation of inactive NiAl2O4 (metal-support interaction) is expected to be minimum for 1 wt% Ga-doped samples. In addition, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 represent reduction peaks at lower temperatures than NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3-W catalyst sample, which confirms the easier reducibility of in-situ doped samples than wet impregnation doped samples. Ga 3d, Ni 2p and Mo 3d XPS patterns for prepared Ga-doped catalyst samples are shown in Figs. 4, 5 and 6 , respectively. For all (Ga wt.% −0.75, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.1) catalyst samples, Ga 3d XPS profile represent three main peaks positioned at 21.2 eV, 24.4 eV and 27.1 eV binding energy values corresponding to Ga-O-Ga (may also come Ga2O3 species or Ga substitution to Al site) Ga-O-Al (Ga substituting Al sites in Al-O-Al bonds of alumina) and Ga-OH (Ga substituting Al-OH groups of alumina) bonds respectively [21]. It is noticed that the Ga-O-Al bond formation peak is the dominant one in all prepared samples, which confirms that Ga has a high affinity to replace Al sites. In addition, the content of Ga-O-Ga increased (1 to 8 % based on XPS area) as Ga doping increased from 0.75 wt% to 2.1 wt% (Fig. 4a-4d) along with almost similar Ga-OH content (a little higher for 2.1 wt% sample) which suggest that Ga substitution to Al sites increase continuously with Ga content and isolated inactive Ga2O3 species content also increase in the sample for higher Ga doping concentrations. This clearly indicates that higher (>1 wt%) Ga doping concentrations ultimately lead to the formation of strong Mo-O-Ga and nickel gallium spinels, which again reduce the HDS activity [21]. Therefore, XPS results suggest that 1 wt% Ga-doped catalyst samples possess higher active sites than all other catalyst samples. In addition, Fig. 5a to d showed Ni 2p XPS profile for NiMo conventional catalyst sample, NiMo@A-Al2O3 sample, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 sample after Ga doping and acid treated Ga doped sample L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 respectively. It is noted from the figure that four different peaks at ∼ 855.5 eV, 852–853 eV, ∼860 eV and 862–863 eV binding energy values are represented in all the samples corresponding to NiMoS, NixSy, NiAl2O4 for and Ni2p satellite phases respectively[19,45]. Based on the Ni2p XPS pattern, NiMoS sites are calculated for various prepared catalyst samples at the same loading by using the following equation (see Table 2 ): (8) NiMoSsites = N Ni × A NiMoS × N W where NNi is the moles of Ni, N is Avagadro number, ANiMoS is the area ratio of NiMoS evaluated using Ni2p XPS (area ratio of NiMoS/(NiMoS + NixSy + NiAl2O4)) and W is the weight of catalyst. The peak corresponding to NiMoS active site is dominant in all the samples (see Table 2). However, NiMoS concentration enhanced significantly (1) By using A-Al2O3 support along with a colloidal synthesis approach (Fig. 5a to b) (2) After Ga doping in A-Al2O3 support (Fig. 5b to c) and (3) After acid leaching treatment of the Ga doped catalyst sample (Fig. 5c to d). Therefore, Ga doping in A-Al2O3 support has successfully replaced the Al tetrahedral sites and reduced the formation of inactive NiAl2O4 spinels. The maximum active sites (93 %) were measured for optimized L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 sample, which makes this material a potential HDS catalyst. For sulfided catalyst samples (Fig. 6a–c), Mo 3d XPS pattern shows five major peaks at around 226.3, 229.5, 232.2, 233.1 and 235.6 eV binding energy values corresponding to S2-, Mo4+ 3d 5/2, Mo4+ 3d 3/2, Mo6+ 3d 5/2 and Mo6+ 3d 3/2 respectively. The presence of Mo4+ oxidation state confirms the formation of MoS2 phase as well as Mo6+ refers to unconverted MoO3 phase during sulfidation process. The sulfidation degree (Fig. 7 ) was calculated based on this Mo 3d XPS spectra, and it described that Ga doping in alumina support enhanced 4–5 % sulfidation degree for NiMo supported catalyst along with maximum sulfidation degree (84 %) for NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 (1 wt% doped samples, XPS pattern in Fig. 6a) catalyst than other Ga composition catalysts. This may be due to its higher reducibility (confirmed by TPR, DFT studies) and Ga-O-Al species (confirmed by Ga 3d XPS). In addition, the acid leached catalyst sample L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 (XPS pattern in Fig. 6b) showed further increment in sulfidation degree (89 %) due to the selective removal of inactive Ni sulfide segregates (confirmed by TEM given in the following section). Further, Ga doped γ-Al2O3 supported control catalyst (NiMo@(1)Ga- γ-Al2O3-W-Wet, XPS pattern in Fig. 6c) also represented enhanced sulfidation degree (75 %) after 1 wt% Ga doping but still it is almost 10 % lesser than NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. S4 represents the FTIR pattern of synthesized catalysts, and the absence of any COOH, CO, or OH group confirms the removal of all the surfactants after calcination [7,8]. The peak at 980 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of the MoO bond of the MoO3 phase. Fig. 8 a–d shows the HRTEM images of 1 wt% Ga doped calcined oxide phase (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3), sulfided phase (sul-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3), wet impregnated control (NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W-Wet) and acid leached (L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) catalyst samples respectively. The HRTEM image (Fig. 8a) confirms the presence of Ni-doped MoO3 (Ni-MoO3) nanoclusters supported on A-Al2O3 with average size 2–3 nm (Eq. (2)). In addition, Fig.S5 also represent the HRTEM images of NiMo nanoclusters before calcination and supported nanoclusters after calcination to confirm that the particles are not agglomerated after calcination. These nanoclusters are sulfided at 30 bar H2 pressure, and all the sulfided samples (Fig. 8b–c) clearly represent the formation NiMoS slabs (Ni doped MoS2 layers) along with inactive NixSy segregates (black patches). In addition, the acid-leached catalyst sample (Fig. 7d) shows the selective removal of inactive Ni sulfide phases and the catalyst possesses a higher number of NiMoS sites. The average stacking distribution/degree, fraction of Mo edge atoms (dispersion) and slab length distribution were also evaluated using HRTEM images of sulfided samples (Eqs. (3)–(5)) and given in Table S1 and Fig. S6. The undoped sulfided catalyst (NiMo@A-Al2O3) reported Mo edge site dispersion (also shown in Table 1) 36 % which is increased to 38 % for 1 wt% Ga doped sample (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3), and it is further enhanced to 41 % for acid leached L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst sample. In addition, all samples reported average slab length of 3–4 nm and stacking degree of 2–3, which are in the desired range for HDS catalysts [2,12,19,42]. This clearly suggests that the prepared Ga doped catalyst samples possess enhanced active metal dispersion along with optimum stacking degree for HDS reaction. 3.2 Computational modelling of the Ga doping in MoS2/Ni doped MoS2 in crystalline and amorphous alumina surfaces The computed lattice parameters (Table S2) and crystal structures of bulk materials (Fig. S7) are given in supporting information. Further, surface energy values of (110) surface of crystalline alumina, amorphous alumina surface, and (100) surface of MoS2 are given in Table S3. In contrast, structures of all surfaces have been shown in Fig. S8. Ga doping has been performed in above mentioned surfaces i.e., in (110) surface of crystalline alumina and amorphous alumina surfaces with bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 adsorbent. The top and side view of Ga Ga-doped substrate with bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 adsorbent is shown in Fig. 9 , which represents a minimal change in the atomic position during the relaxation of the system. The adsorption energy values of bare MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 on Ga doped crystalline ((110) surface) and amorphous substrate are given in Table 3 along with both substrates without Ga doping. The adsorption energy values of bare MoS2 suggest that its adsorption on Ga-doped amorphous surface has the lowest energy (−2.12 eV) in comparison to crystalline alumina (−3.74 eV) as well as Ga-doped crystalline alumina (−2.95 eV). These results suggest that the interaction of bare MoS2 is weaker at amorphous alumina than crystalline alumina. Further, the adsorption of Ni-doped MoS2 on both the Ga-doped crystalline and amorphous alumina surfaces also follow the same trend i.e., Ni-doped MoS2 adsorbent posses weaker interaction on Ga-doped amorphous alumina surface as compared to Ga doped crystalline (110) surface. In addition, these results also confirm that the metal support interaction is weaker for Ga-doped alumina surfaces than bare alumina surfaces, suggesting that the Ga doping increased the reducibility of the substrate. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity results for synthesized catalyst samples are shown in Figs. 10–12 for dibenzothiophene (DBT) and 4,6 dimethyl dibenzothiophene (4,6 DMDBT) reactant molecules. Before starting the activity tests, the catalyst particles were made in the optimized size range 0.25–0.30 mm using 52–60 mesh sieves to avoid the effect of internal and external mass transfer resistances. All the reaction runs were performed at fixed flowrate 0.17 ml/min and pressure 30 bar; however, the temperature was varied in the range 275-335 ℃. The activity results of DBT reactant molecule for various Ga-doped catalyst samples represent that the conversion increased with temperature (rate constant is proportional to temperature), and it became almost the same for all catalysts at higher temperature values (320–335 ℃) because the reaction rate is only dependent on temperature in this region. It is observed in Fig. 10 that 1 wt% Ga-doped samples report higher DBT conversion than all other (0.75–2.1 wt%) Ga-doped samples for both types of doping (in-situ and wet impregnation) samples. However, at fixed Ga doping content, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst prepared by in-situ doping possess enhanced activity than NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3-W catalyst synthesized via wet impregnation doping. It concludes that the potential catalyst synthesis method is in-situ Ga doping. Therefore, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 was screened and compared further to all the prepared control and reference catalysts in Fig. 11, which shows that it exhibits 14 % and 28 % increment in DBT conversion from undoped reference samples NiMo@A-Al2O3 and NiMo@γ-Al2O3-Wet respectively. In addition, this catalyst (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) also reported 18 % and 8 % activity increment from Ga-doped wet impregnated control samples NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3-Wet and NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W-Wet respectively. Further, this catalyst, after acid leaching treatment (L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) showed remarkable DBT conversion (91 % at 275 ℃) values. This suggest that the activity is affected by all the parameters such as preparation method, catalyst support, acid treatment and Ga doping. In this regard, this higher activity may be demonstrated due to the A-Al2O3 support as well as Ga doping in A-Al2O3 ensuring weak-metal support interaction leading to higher sulfidation degree and Ni availability for NiMoS site formation (confirmed by TPR, DFT and XPS), colloidal synthesis approach producing higher active metal dispersion (confirmed by HRTEM) and removal of inactive Ni sulfides through acid leaching (confirmed by HRTEM). The highly active screened catalysts (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 and L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) were also tested for HDS reaction of heavier molecule like 4, 6 DMDBT and compared with prepared control catalysts (Fig. 12). It is noticed that the maximum conversion was observed for L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst (40 % higher than undoped convention catalyst NiMo@γ-Al2O3-Wet at 275 ℃) and a significant activity increment was noticed from 28 % to 42 % for NiMo@A-Al2O3 catalysts after Ga doping. Therefore, it is clear that the prepared catalysts are active enough to target the refractory heavier sulfur compounds, making these catalysts a potential solution for SOx emissions. As described earlier, HDS reaction can follow two different routs 1) Direct desulfurization (DDS) 2) Hydrogenation followed by desulfurization (HYD). Biphenyl (BP) and cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) are the two major products of DDS and HYD pathways respectively for HDS reaction of DBT [2,8,9,57]. In this regard, the collected products of HDS reaction for DBT reactant, were analyzed using GC and the product selectivity graph is shown in Fig. 13 . The production distribution clearly describe that BP is the dominant product for all catalyst samples and its content decreases continuously with temperature. This may be due to the enhanced hydrogenation ability of the catalysts with temperature, which generate higher CHB consequently reducing BP formation. In addition, it is noticed that at fixed temperature, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst possesses higher HYD selectivity than all the control conventional samples and it is increased further after acid treatment (L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3). Therefore, it is worth to mention the higher activity of the prepared Ga-doped catalyst samples is based on the enhanced type 2 NiMoS sites (confirmed by TPR, XPS, DFT and HRTEM) which actually favor HYD pathways as these sites are more suitable for planar adsorption than type 1 sites. 3.4 Stability Based on the properties and activity test of DBT and 4,6 DMDBT reactant molecules, NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst sample was screened for longer reaction run stability test experiment. Fig. 14 clearly represents that no significant changes were observed in DBT conversion as well as the product distribution for 80-hour reaction run period at 335 ℃. This suggests that the prepared catalyst sample is highly stable for long reaction runs, making it an potential catalyst for the HDS industrial process. 3.5 Kinetics To understand the catalysts performance in detail, the reaction rate constant for both reaction pathways as well as the turnover frequency (TOF, Eq. (5)) were also calculated and shown in Table 4 . The pseudo first order HDS reaction was performed in a fixed bed reactor following the plug flow reactor characteristics and the proposed rate law is given here in Eqs. (9)–(11). (9) ln 1 1 - X = k HDS W F (10) k DDS = k HDS × S DDS (11) k HYD = k HDS × S HYD Here, kHDS is the reaction rate constant for HDS process, W is the catalyst weight, X is the DBT conversion at a given temperature, NMo is the mol of molybdenum, fMo is the Mo edge sites fraction, N is Avogadro number, kDDS and kHYD are the rate constant for DDS and HYD pathways, SDDS and SHYD are the selectivity for DDS and HYD reaction pathways (determined by the fraction of BP and CHB formation respectively (product distribution)). and F the molar flow rate of the reactant [58]. Table 4 clearly showed that the reaction rate constant (kHDS) for reference NiMo@A-Al2O3 and NiMo@γ-Al2O3--Wet catalysts without Ga doping, were 742.6 and 514.5 μmol/h which increased to 1107.1 and 689 μmol/h after doping 1 wt% Ga in catalyst supports respectively. In addition, as described earlier based on the activity trend, A-Al2O3 supported catalysts (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3) represent higher rate constant (1107.1 μmol/h) than γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst (NiMo@(1)Ga-γ-Al2O3-W, 974.7 μmol/h). However, A-Al2O3 supported catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 –Wet) posses lower rate constant (689 μmol/h) than NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 prepared by colloidal synthesis. This clearly describe that the 1 wt% Ga doped A-Al2O3 supported catalysts prepared by colloidal synthesis method (NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3), demonstrate superior HDS reaction constant which further enhanced to 1516.1 μmol/h after acid leaching treatment. The extensive shoot up of HDS performance can be directly related to higher number of NiMoS active sites produced through greater participation of Ni promoter in NiMoS site formation via Ga doping, higher reducibility or sulfidation degree of A-Al2O3 support and better MoS2 dispersion along with selective removal of inactive Ni sulfide segregates. Further, kDDS and kHYD constants explained that the HDS reaction favored the DDS pathways dominantly for all catalyst samples but the kHYD constant enhanced significantly after Ga doping and acid leaching treatment. It is worth to notice that the higher performance of NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 and L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst may be related to their higher HYD selectivity which is ultimately controlled by type 2 NiMoS active sites which enable the planar adsorption of bigger sulfur compounds. TOF further supported the catalytic activity and reaction rate constant trend for prepared catalyst samples and demonstrated that the maximum TOF was reported for L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 (2.55x10-4 s−1) as well as enhanced TOF was observed for NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst (2.41x10-4 s−1) than reference NiMo@A-Al2O3 catalyst without Ga doping (A TOF comparison table is also given as Table S4). Therefore, it may be summarized that the Ga doping approach in catalyst support along with acid leaching treatment has shown remarkable performance for HDS reaction. 3.6 Discussion Ga-doped NiMo supported on amorphous alumina catalysts were successfully prepared using a colloidal synthesis approach. In this work, catalysts were compared based on the (1) Preparation method (wet impregnation and colloidal synthesis), (2) Support (γ-Al2O3 and A-Al2O3) (3) Ga doping effects and (4) Removal of inactive NixSy sites. (1) In colloidal synthesis approach, NiMo oxide nanocatalysts are solution grown nanometer size particles stabilized by surfactants layer over the surface of the particles. It is very controlled/stable way of synthesizing nanocatalysts. However, in wet impregnation method, metals are deposited on the support surface by evaporating the excess precursor solutions and it generally suffers the lack of control over the particle size of the catalysts. In this work, ultrasmall bimetallic catalysts prepared by colloidal synthesis approach possess higher surface area and better control over particle size/growth (confirmed by BET), compared to the conventional impregnated samples. This leads to enhanced active metal dispersion/uniformity for the prepared catalysts. (2) Various characterization (BET, TPR, HRTEM) results confirmed that A-Al2O3 supported catalysts possess low surface energy/higher reducibility than γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts [54,59,60]. Because A-Al2O3 structure comprises of four [Al]4 and (undercoordinated) five [Al]5 coordinated sites dominantly (95 %) along with few six [Al]6 coordinated sites, which leads to more unsaturated lewis acid sites compared to γ-Al2O3 (structure consists of [Al]4 and [Al]6 sites). This generates enhanced Ni-Mo interactions (NiMoS active sites) or weak Mo-Al2O3 (Mo-O-Al) interactions. (3) During Ga doping, it substituted the tetrahedral Al sites in A-Al2O3 support (confirmed by XPS) and formed GaAl2O4 phases, which made the Ni promoter free from support (by inhibiting the formation of inactive NiAl2O4 species, Ni2p XPS), leading to its enhanced participation in the formation of NiMoS active sites. Adding an optimized Ga amount also further increased the Mo sulfidation degree due to its higher reducibility (lower metal-support interactions) and dispersion on the catalyst surface [21,36]. (4) Finally, the inactive isolated NixSy segregates were removed by acid leaching method for Ga-doped sulfided NiMo catalysts and it increased the number of active NiMoS sites for HDS reaction. Because earlier these sites were covered by inactive NixSy segregates and not participating in the reaction. All these points conclude that this catalyst simultaneously addressed all the following problems:inactive NiAl2O4 species, inactive NixSy segregates and strong Mo-O-Al bond, for superior HDS activity [12,20,21]. 4 Conclusion Ga doping study has successfully carried out for prepared NiMo@A-Al2O3 catalysts and represented that Ga addition enhanced the HDS activity not only by increasing the NiMo interactions through replacement of Ga at Al sites but also promoting Mo sulfidation. However, higher amount of Ga prefers to form strong Mo-O-Ga bond along with Ga2O3 isolated phases which decrease the HDS activity. The DFT studies are also performed to support the importance of Ga doping experimental studies and the calculated adsorption energy values suggested that the metal support interaction is weaker for Ga doped alumina surfaces as compared to bare alumina surfaces for both bare MoS2 and Ni doped MoS2 adsorbates. This work also proposed acid leached L-NiMo@(1)Ga-A-Al2O3 catalyst, which further increased the HDS performance by removing inactive Ni sulfide phases from catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction activity depends on the formation of active NiMoS (completely sulfided multilayer type 2 sites) and inactive NiAl2O4/NixSy phases on the catalyst surface. These inactive phases not only itself inactive for the reaction but also hinder the formation of active NiMoS phases. In addition, the formation of strong Mo-O-Al bonds also lowers the reducibility of the catalyst, suggesting lesser catalytic activity (type 1 sites, partially sulfided single-layer sites). To this end, we report the formation of NiMo/Ga doped amorphous alumina (A-Al2O3) catalysts prepared by the colloidal synthesis method. A-Al2O3 was chosen as a support because it has lower surface energy, better physicochemical properties, and enhanced acidic sites than the crystalline alumina phase, which favours the formation of type 2 sites or weak metal-support interaction (completely sulfided multilayer NiMoS sites). Further, the Ga doping in A-Al2O3 support substitute the tetrahedral Al sites and form GaAl2O4 phases by reducing NiAl2O4 inactive sites, and the free Ni decorate the edges of MoS2 to form HDS active NiMoS sites. Therefore, NiMo/Ga doped A-Al2O3 catalyst (at 1 wt% Ga loading) reported enhanced HDS catalytic activity (25%), HDS reaction rate constant (kHDS-2.15 times) and turn over frequency (TOF-1.3 times) than the conventional NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Suppression of inactive sites in NiMo@amorphous alumina catalysts for hydrodesulfurization reaction: Effect of Ga doping
